docs.snippet: Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez, who retires in March, has handled three of the era's most important cases: Enron, WorldCom and Chrysler....
docs.lead_paragraph: Many judges are lucky to handle just one era-defining case during their tenures on the bench. In his 16 years as a federal bankruptcy judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez has handled three.
docs.abstract: Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez, who retires in March, has handled three of the era's most important cases: Enron, WorldCom and Chrysler.

headline.main: A Judge Who Reshaped the Corporate Landscape

docs.snippet: David Chao — a general partner at DCM, a major Renren shareholder — talks about why his firm is holding its stake in the Facebook of China, the long-term value of the social networking site and the recent accounting questions at the company....
docs.lead_paragraph: Many of Renren’s investors profited handsomely from the company’s initial public offering, when shares priced at $14 on Wednesday. But a venture capital firm, DCM, which owns 7.5 percent of the Chinese social networking site, is holding on to its stake.

docs.snippet: Jeffrey K. Skilling asserted that controversial financing vehicles were not intended to hide losses but rather were meant to protect gains....
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey K. Skilling responded to charges that he participated in a fraud to move $200 million in losses from one Enron unit to another by saying that there was no loss to move and no fraud to hide. Mr. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, was testifying for a third day at his federal fraud and conspiracy trial, which is in its 11th week. He also denied that Enron had ever used ''cookie jar reserves'' to fill earnings gaps, as government witnesses have alleged, insisting that Enron used reserves only for specified purposes.
docs.abstract: Former Enron chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling denies fraud charges on third day of testimony at federal trial; responds to charges that he participated in fraud to move $200 million in losses from one unit to another by saying no loss existed and no fraud occurred; Skilling and former chief executive Kenneth L Lay are accused of conspiring to defraud investors in Enron, which went bankrupt in 2001; photo (M)

headline.main: Ex-Enron Chief Defends Shift of Contracts

docs.snippet: Inside the company, they were called the Friends of Enron, and they were among the energy company's secret financial weapons.    Repeatedly during the late 1990's, the Enron Corporation turned to a small group of wealthy Houston residents to inves...
docs.lead_paragraph: Inside the company, they were called the Friends of Enron, and they were among the energy company's secret financial weapons. Repeatedly during the late 1990's, the Enron Corporation turned to a small group of wealthy Houston residents to invest in a series of private partnerships that helped the company manage its financial results.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp turned to small group of wealthy Houston residents called Friends of Enron during late 1990's to invest in series of private partnerships that helped company manage its financial results; investors served as presumably independent third parties in transactions that let Enron shift certain investments and related debts off its books; many in group were friends of Enron's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow; two names have surfaced so far; one is Kathy Wetmore, Fastow's real estate broker who also did real estate work for Jeffrey K Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, and Michael J Kopper, former managing director at Enron who helped manage partnerships; other investor, Patty Melcher, is longtime friend of Fastow's wife Lea; Mrs Fastow is heiress to Houston real estate fortune; Ms Melcher's husband is heir to Houston-based chain of convenience stores; two women's names were disclosed in summary of interview conducted in January by special investigative committee of Enron's board with Kristina Mordaunt, herself former Enron lawyer fired by company last fall for making unauthorized investment in similar deal; Ms Melcher says Fastow and other Enron executives approached her about investing in about eight deals over years and that she participated in five; adds she had millions at stake in deals, with investments ranging from $100,000 to $2 million; Duke University Prof Steven L Schwarcz, who is expert on off-the-balance-sheet partnerships, says deals between Enron and friends of its executives are unusual; photo (M)

headline.main: Some Houstonians Whom Enron Called Friends

docs.snippet: Michael W. Ramsey said that doctors discovered on Friday that a blockage he had was severe enough to require a stent....
docs.lead_paragraph: For weeks, people around the court had suspected that something beyond the government's case against his client was bothering Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron. Mr. Ramsey shuffled uncomfortably around the federal courthouse, often looking glassy-eyed and lingering for long periods in the bathroom.
docs.abstract: Michael Ramsey, lead lawyer for former Enron chief executive Kenneth Lay, confirms that he had operation to implant heart stent during trial; says he feels much better and that he will remain in trial, which is expected to last at least another four weeks; photo (M)

headline.main: Lay Lawyer Had Emergency Heart Procedure Last Week

docs.snippet: Ten former Enron directors have agreed to pay $13 million out of their own pockets as part of a settlement with onetime shareholders....
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of 10 former directors of Enron have agreed to pay $13 million out of their own pockets as part of a $168 million settlement of a lawsuit brought by onetime shareholders who lost billions of dollars in the company's collapse in 2001. The announcement of the agreement, reached confidentially in October, came just days after former directors of WorldCom agreed to pay $18 million of their own money as part of a $54 million settlement with former shareholders whose investments were wiped out by the 2002 bankruptcy of the company.
docs.abstract: Ten former Enron Corp directors agree to pay $13 million out of their own pockets as part of $168 million settlement of lawsuit brought by onetime shareholders who lost billions of dollars in company's collapse in 2001; settlement has broader implications for former executives who were not part of agreement, including former chmn Kenneth L Lay and former chief exec Jeffrey K Skilling; insurance proceeds protecting Enron's former directors and officers have been depleted with deal; Lay and other officers still have $13 million in insurance available to pay legal fees, but they will have to pay future judgments against them with their own money or personal insurance (M)

headline.main: Ex-Directors Of Enron To Chip In On Settlement
